awd_titl_txt: CBMS Conference: Deep Learning and Numerical Partial Differential Equations
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides support for the Conference Board of the Mathematical Sciences conference "Deep Learning and Numerical PDEs," to be held at Morgan State University in Baltimore, June 19-24, 2023. This conference will bring together experts from mathematics, computer science, and engineering on topics involving deep learning and numerical partial differential equations (PDEs). As such, it will provide an education platform and forum for experts and young researchers to communicate new advancements in theoretical and application developments. The interaction between theory and application experts is intended to spark new ideas and collaborative projects. The conference will fund approximately 30 participants, especially graduate students, postdoctoral associates, early-career researchers, and individuals from underrepresented groups. The meeting aims to provide extraordinary opportunities to the participants to study the fundamental mathematical theory of deep learning, communicate potential important research directions, discuss possible practical applications, and interact with leading researchers.
 
The distinguished principal lecturer will be Verne M. Willaman Professor Jinchao Xu of Pennsylvania State University. The lectures will present the latest developments on the theory and applications of deep learning, bridging models and algorithms from two different fields: (1) machine learning, including logistic regression and deep neural networks, and (2) numerical PDEs, including finite element and multigrid methods. The lecture series builds upon a discussion on the latest developments in machine learning models and algorithms and presents cutting-edge research on intrinsically connected topics to the participants of the conference. As a result, this conference is expected to bring novel insights into the understanding of deep learning, and to further promote their analysis and applications in different scientific and engineering fields. For more information, please refer to the conference webpage: 
https://sites.google.com/view/nsf-cbms-dl-nmpde/home

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The conference serves as a platform to educate graduate students and young researchers, with a particular focus on those from underrepresented groups, by providing them with opportunities to learn about the theory of deep learning through conference attendance. Additionally, it aims to facilitate networking and knowledge exchange among experts, students, and young faculty members in the fields of machine learning and numerical partial differential equations (PDEs), fostering discussions on both theoretical advancements and practical applications.

The Principal Lecturer, Dr. Jinchao Xu, delivered 10 lectures covering topics such as the mathematical theory of deep neural networks, optimization algorithms in machine learning, deep neural networks for PDEs and their mathematical foundations, as well as fast, efficient, and interpretable learning models and algorithms for PDEs, alongside practical applications to real-world problems. The conference attracted over 100 attendees both in person and virtually, representing a diverse group including local and national graduate students, women researchers and students, individuals from national labs, and international students. Additionally, the conference featured 16 external speakers and approximately 10 young scholars who delivered short talks. Financial support was prioritized for young and early-career participants, facilitating their attendance. Local participants and faculty members took advantage of the opportunity to network and engage with experts in applied computational mathematics from around the world, exchanging ideas, exploring research topics, and identifying potential collaboration opportunities.

 

This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content


Last Modified: 03/09/2024
Modified by: Mingchao Cai
